headline.print_headline: New Mexico Commission Limits Drug Use in Racing
headline.seo: New Mexico Commission Limits Drug Use in Horse Racing
headline.main: New Mexico Commission Limits Drug Use in Horse Racing

docs.snippet: New Mexico adopted new rules that limit the use of drugs in the state’s horse racing industry and impose tougher penalties for drug use....
docs.abstract: New Mexico Racing Commission votes unanimously to limit the use of drugs in the state’s horse racing industry and to impose tougher penalties on those who run afoul of its rules; New Mexico joins a small number of racing jurisdictions with the lowest allowable levels of two widely used pain suppressants.
docs.lead_paragraph: New Mexico adopted new rules that limit the use of drugs in the state’s horse racing industry and impose tougher penalties for drug use.

headline.print_headline: To Tackle an Invasive Weed, Bringing In the Hooved Pros
headline.seo: At Freshkills Park, Borrowing Goats to Tackle a Weed Problem
headline.main: To Tackle an Invasive Weed, Bringing In the Hooved Pros

docs.snippet: The New York City parks department is renting 20 goats to help fight phragmites at a Staten Island site that is soon to become Freshkills Park....
docs.abstract: New York City Parks Dept is enlisting 20 goats to help fight phragmites, invasive weed choking the Staten Island shoreline; officials are counting on the goats to clear phragmites from two acres of wetlands that will eventually be restored and made a part of Freshkills Park.
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York City parks department is renting 20 goats to help fight phragmites at a Staten Island site that is soon to become Freshkills Park.

docs.snippet: In ruling that the F.C.C. was wrong to conclude that Fox and ABC had violated indecency standards, the Supreme Court gives notice that the commission should rewrite its policy....
docs.abstract: Editorial agrees with the Supreme Court decision that the Federal Communications Commission was wrong to conclude that Fox Television and ABC had violated indecency standards for a couple of fleeting expletives and seven seconds of partial nudity; urges the FCC to implement the court's suggestion that it modify its indecency policy.
docs.lead_paragraph: In ruling that the F.C.C. was wrong to conclude that Fox and ABC had violated indecency standards, the Supreme Court gives notice that the commission should rewrite its policy.

headline.print_headline: NBC News Faces Shift In Television Dominance
headline.seo: NBC News Faces Shift in Television Dominance
headline.main: NBC News Faces Shift in Television Dominance

docs.snippet: As ratings across its weekday morning, nightly and Sunday morning franchises decline, the network appears vulnerable....
docs.abstract: NBC News has long been a dominant presence on network television, but as ratings across its weekday morning, nightly and Sunday morning franchises decline, the network appears vulnerable; the most visible manifestation is Today, a profit center for the division, which is down about 4 percent in total viewers over the past year and about 9 percent in the vital 25-54 age group.

byline.original: By BILL CARTER and BRIAN STELTER

docs.lead_paragraph: As ratings across its weekday morning, nightly and Sunday morning franchises decline, the network appears vulnerable.

headline.print_headline: Union, on Heels of Wisconsin Recall Vote, Selects a New President
headline.seo: Union, on Heels of Wisconsin Recall Vote, Selects a New President
headline.main: Union, on Heels of Wisconsin Recall Vote, Selects a New President

docs.snippet: At their convention, the Afscme delegates elevated the union’s secretary-treasurer, Lee Saunders....

keywords.value: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees
keywords.name: organizations

docs.abstract: Nearly 3,000 delegates attend the convention of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees in Los Angeles; Lee Saunders is elected president, and vows to increase the union's membership of almost 1.4 million; Afscme is on the defensive as never before, reeling from Wisconsin's law, championed by Gov Scott Walker, that curbs public employees' ability to bargain collectively.
docs.lead_paragraph: At their convention, the Afscme delegates elevated the union’s secretary-treasurer, Lee Saunders.

headline.print_headline: Democrats Seek New Reports On New Jersey Halfway Houses
headline.seo: New Jersey Democrats Call for Greater Oversight of Halfway-House System
headline.main: Democrats Seek New Reports on New Jersey Halfway Houses

docs.snippet: Lawmakers called for stricter oversight of the system of prisoner re-entry centers, saying new requirements would lead to “better safety for our communities.”...
docs.abstract: Democrats in New Jersey's Legislature call for stricter oversight of the state's troubled system of halfway houses; say new disclosure requirements would lead to both to safer communities and safer conditions for residents of the privately run system, which has beds for roughly 3,500 state inmates and parolees; in addition, every halfway-house operator that contracts with the Corrections Dept would have to undergo a financial audit.
docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers called for stricter oversight of the system of prisoner re-entry centers, saying new requirements would lead to “better safety for our communities.”

headline.print_headline: Threat of Fierce Wildfires Grows in West as Vintage Air Arsenal Shrinks
headline.seo: Fire Threat Up as Vintage Air Arsenal Shrinks
headline.main: Fire Threat Up as Vintage Air Arsenal Shrinks

docs.snippet: As the threat of wildfires grows in the West, the fleet of planes used to fight them is aging and depleted....
docs.abstract: Contractor-owned planes, refurbished from military use and leased by the United States Forest Service to fight wildfires, have been hobbled by accidents and mechanical problems, leading to growing safety concerns and calls for a major overhaul; federal authorities have relied increasingly on the fleet of ancient planes as they confront the start of a fierce wildfire season.

byline.original: By JACK HEALY and MATTHEW L. WALD
byline.contributor: Jack Healy reported from Broomfield, Colo., and Matthew L. Wald from Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the threat of wildfires grows in the West, the fleet of planes used to fight them is aging and depleted.

headline.print_headline: Six-Year Sentence in Theft Of Millions in Union Funds
headline.seo: 6-Year Sentence for Melissa G. King, Who Stole Millions From Sandhogs Union
headline.main: Six-Year Sentence in Theft of Millions in Union Funds

docs.snippet: Federal prosecutors contend that Melissa G. King stole $40 million from the benefit plans that she ran for Local 147, whose members dig the city’s giant water and train tunnels....
docs.abstract: Melissa G King is sentenced to six years for embezzlement and filing false income tax returns; federal prosecutors contend that King stole $40 million from the benefit plans that she administered for Local 147, whose union members dig the city’s giant water and train tunnels.
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors contend that Melissa G. King stole $40 million from the benefit plans that she ran for Local 147, whose members dig the city’s giant water and train tunnels.

headline.print_headline: Ruling Confirms Jury’s Role in Raising Criminal Sentences
headline.seo: Supreme Court’s Southern Union Ruling Limits Judges
headline.main: Ruling Confirms Jury’s Role in Raising Criminal Sentences

docs.snippet: Overturning a fine levied against the pipeline operator Southern Union, the court ruled that juries, not judges, had to decide the facts that increased a defendant’s sentence....
docs.lead_paragraph: Overturning a fine levied against the pipeline operator Southern Union, the court ruled that juries, not judges, had to decide the facts that increased a defendant’s sentence.

headline.print_headline: For Gatlin, Brash Talk and Renewed Confidence
headline.seo: For Justin Gatlin, Brash Talk and Renewed Confidence
headline.main: For Gatlin, Brash Talk and Renewed Confidence

docs.snippet: Justin Gatlin, the 2004 Olympic gold medalist in the 100-meter dash, is undergoing a physical rejuvenation and an emotional resurgence after a four-year drug ban....
docs.abstract: Justin Gatlin, the 2004 Olympic gold medalist in the 100-meter dash, has undergone a physical rejuvenation and an emotional resurgence after a four-year drug ban, and hopes that the United States Olympics Trials will show that he is still the star he once was.
docs.lead_paragraph: Justin Gatlin, the 2004 Olympic gold medalist in the 100-meter dash, is undergoing a physical rejuvenation and an emotional resurgence after a four-year drug ban.
